6.SP.2.explanation: Both centers are 10, but Set A range is 0 while Set B range is 8, so Set B is more spread out.

choices.label: A
choices.text: Both sets have the same center and same spread.
choices.misconception_text: Oops! While they both have the same center (10), Set B is definitely more spread out since the numbers aren't all the same!

choices.label: B
choices.text: Both sets have center 10, but Set B has greater spread.

choices.label: C
choices.text: Set A has greater spread because all values are 10.
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. Since all the numbers in Set A are identical, it actually has zero spread! Set B has much more variety.

choices.label: D
choices.text: Set B has center 12 and smaller spread.
choices.misconception_text: Careful! The center of Set B is actually 10, and it's much more spread out than Set A is.

6.SP.2.stem: Which description correctly uses center, spread, and shape?
6.SP.2.explanation: Data distributions are summarized by center (typical value), spread (variability), and shape (pattern).

choices.label: A
choices.text: Center is where most data lie, spread is how far values vary, and shape describes pattern of distribution.

choices.label: B
choices.text: Center is always the largest value, spread is always zero, and shape is not useful.
choices.misconception_text: Oops! It looks like those definitions got mixed up. Center, spread, and shape are all very helpful tools for understanding our data!

choices.label: C
choices.text: Center and spread are the same thing.
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. Center tells us where the middle of the group is, while spread tells us how far away the other numbers are from that middle point!

choices.label: D
choices.text: Shape is only for geometry, not data.
choices.misconception_text: Careful with that! In statistics, "shape" is actually a very important way to describe how data values are clustered together.

6.SP.3.stem: Which is a measure of center?
6.SP.3.explanation: Measures of center include mean and median. Range, IQR, and MAD are spread measures.

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Oops! The range actually tells us how spread out all the data is, instead of finding the middle point!

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. The interquartile range is a way to measure variability, or how much the data fluctuates.

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful! This measures how far data points tend to be from the mean, so it's a measure of variation rather than the center.

6.SP.3.stem: Which quantity best describes how far data values tend to be from the mean?
6.SP.3.explanation: MAD summarizes average distance from the mean, a measure of variation.

choices.label: A
choices.misconception_text: Oops! Median is a measure of center. We're looking for a special value that tells us about the "spread" or gap between points!

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. Mode just tells us which single value shows up most often, not about the distances between numbers.

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful! Adding everything up tells us the total value, but it doesn't describe how far apart the numbers are from each other.

6.SP.3.stem: Data Set A and B both have mean 20. Set A values are tightly clustered near 20, Set B values are widely spread. What is true?
6.SP.3.explanation: Both sets have the same center (mean 20), but different spread.

choices.label: A
choices.text: Both center and variation are the same
choices.misconception_text: Oops! While the centers (means) match, the data in Set B is spread out much further, which means the variation is different!

choices.label: B
choices.text: Center is same, variation is different

choices.label: C
choices.text: Variation is same, center is different
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. We know the means are both 20, so the center is the sameโit's the "spread" or variation that differs!

choices.label: D
choices.text: Neither center nor variation can be compared
choices.misconception_text: Careful! We actually have all the information we need here to see that the center matches while the variation does not.

6.SP.3.stem: For data 4, 6, 8, which statement is correct?

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Oops! It looks like those two values were swapped. 6 is our average (mean) and 4 is the total gap (range)!

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Almost! It looks like the range was only measured between neighbors. For the real range, just use the max minus the min (8 - 4).

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful with your centers! 8 is our largest number, but for the mean, we want the average of the whole group!

6.SP.3.stem: Why is it useful to report both a measure of center and a measure of variation?
6.SP.3.explanation: Center summarizes location; variation summarizes spread. Both are needed to describe a distribution.

choices.label: A
choices.text: Because center alone describes everything about a data set
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. Hmm, center is great for found the middle, but it doesn't give us any clues about whether the data is gathered together or spread way out!

choices.label: B
choices.text: Because variation alone gives the typical value
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. Variation tells us how spread out things are, but we need the center to find the "typical" or middle result!

choices.label: C
choices.text: Because center shows a typical value and variation shows how values differ around it

choices.label: D
choices.text: Because both numbers are always equal
choices.misconception_text: Oops! Center and variation are actually two different ways of analyzing data, so they are almost never exactly the same!

6.SP.5.stem: A report says: 'Class average height is 152.' What key context detail is missing?
6.SP.5.explanation: A meaningful summary must include units (for example, centimeters).

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Oops! While colors catch the eye, they don't change what the data actually means. We need to know if 152 is cm, inches, or something else!

choices.label: C
choices.text: Whether the average is an integer
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. Whether it's a whole number or not is much less important than knowing what's being measured!

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful with the details! More decimals might add precision, but knowing the units (like cm) is the most critical part here.

6.SP.5.stem: Which item is a quantitative measure of variability?
6.SP.5.explanation: IQR and MAD are variability measures used to summarize spread.

choices.label: A
choices.misconception_text: Oops! Median is a measure of center. We're looking for a special measure that tells us how much the data varies or spreads apart.

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. Mode just tells us which value appears most often, not about the overall spread of the whole data set!

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful! Sample size only tells us how many pieces of data we collected, not how much those pieces differ from each other.

6.SP.5.stem: Data are test scores: 71, 73, 72, 74, 95. Which statement best summarizes shape and deviations?
6.SP.5.explanation: Four values cluster in low 70s, while 95 is strikingly larger.

choices.label: A
choices.text: All scores are clustered near 73 with one high outlier-like value 95

choices.label: B
choices.text: Scores are perfectly symmetric with no unusual values
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. Hmm, if we look closely, that score of 95 is much bigger than everything else in the 70sโit's definitely an unusual result for this group!

choices.label: C
choices.text: Scores show two equal clusters around 72 and 95
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. Since we only have one score at 95, it's more like an outlier than a whole separate "cluster" of numbers.

choices.label: D
choices.text: Scores cannot be summarized because there are only five values
choices.misconception_text: Careful! Even with just a few data points, we can still see patterns and describe their general layout.

6.SP.5.stem: Which summary is most complete for a numerical data set?
6.SP.5.explanation: A full summary includes sample size, attribute and units, center, variation, and distribution features.

choices.label: A
choices.misconception_text: Oops! The mean is important, but it doesn't give the whole story, like how many points there are or how spread out they might be!

choices.label: B
choices.text: Count, what was measured with units, center, variability, and notable patterns/deviations

choices.label: C
choices.text: Only a graph title and axis labels
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. Labels are super helpful, but a complete summary also needs to explain what the actual numbers are telling us about the data!

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful! Knowing the top and bottom scores is a good start, but we also want to understand what's happening in the middle.

6.SP.5.stem: Two classes have the same mean quiz score. Class A has much larger IQR than Class B. What conclusion is valid?
6.SP.5.explanation: Larger IQR indicates greater spread in the middle half of the data.

choices.label: A
choices.text: Class A scores are more spread out

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Oops! The question tells us that both classes have exactly the same mean, so their centers are already identical.

choices.label: C
choices.text: Class B must have more students
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. The IQR is all about the spread of the scores, it doesn't really tell us how many students were in the class!

choices.label: D
choices.text: The two classes have identical distributions
choices.misconception_text: Careful with your comparisons! Since Class A has a wider spread, their distributions are different even if their averages happen to match.

7.EE.1.explanation: Distribute first: 6x - 15 + 4x, then combine like terms to get 10x - 15.

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Oops! It looks like the 3 only multiplied the 2x. Make sure to share that 3 with the 5 as well!

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. We can't combine -15 and 4x because they aren't "like terms." It's best to keep them separate.

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful! Let's re-add those x's: 6x plus 4x should give us exactly 10x in total.

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Oops! While 14 is at the front, it doesn't divide evenly into 21. We're looking for a factor that both 14 and 21 have in common!

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. 3 works perfectly for 21, but it doesn't quite work for 14. Let's try 7 instead!

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Almost! You found the right common factor (7), but don't forget to divide that 21 by 7 too!

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Oops! Watch out for those minus signs. Remember that a negative times a negative (like -2 times -4) turns into a positive!

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. It seems there was a tiny sign error when combining -6a and 5a. Let's check that math once more.

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful! We need to fully distribute the numbers into the groups before we can start adding up all the a's.

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Oops! It looks like the -3 accidentally became a +3. Let's keep that subtraction sign through to the final answer.

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. When you have 4x and subtract 1.5x, you should end up with a smaller number of x's!

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful with all the pieces! It seems some steps might have been skipped or mixed together. Let's take it one step at a time.

7.EE.1.explanation: First combine to 18m - 18, then factor out 6: 6(3m - 3).

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Oops! It looks like only the first 12m was used. We should combine 12m and 6m into 18m *before* we start our factoring!

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. While this math is correct, we can pull out even more than a 3! Let's find the *greatest* common factor.

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. It looks like you simplified the expression perfectly! Now, for the very last step, see if you can pull out a common factor from both 18m and 18.

7.EE.2.stem: A gym charges 12 dollars monthly plus 3 dollars per class. Which expression shows total cost for c classes?
7.EE.2.explanation: Fixed fee is 12 and variable fee is 3 per class, so total is 12 + 3c.

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Oops! This would mean the $12 fee repeats for every class you take. The $12 is a one-time monthly fee!

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. This would multiply the $12 fee by 3. We only want the 3 multiplied by the number of classes (c).

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful! It seems the fee and the per-class price got swapped in their spots.

7.EE.2.stem: Which rewrite best shows that 3(x + 2) + x has a common factor?

choices.label: A
choices.misconception_text: Oops! It looks like the 3 didn't quite get multiplied by the 2 inside the parentheses. Let's try distributing that 3 again!

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. It looks like you simplified it perfectly! Now, for one more step, see if you can find a common number to pull out of both 4 and 6.

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful with the factoring! It looks like some variables were pulled out that didn't quite belong.

7.EE.2.stem: A store gives 20% discount on an item priced p dollars, then adds 5 dollars shipping. Which equivalent expression for final cost is most useful?
7.EE.2.explanation: After 20% off, pay 80% of p, then add fixed shipping: 0.8p + 5.

choices.label: A
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. This math is definitely correct! We're just looking for the *most* simplified version, like using 0.8p to show the discount.

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Oops! 1.2p would actually mean the price went *up* by 20%. For a discount, we want to subtract 20% from the whole.

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful! This would take 20% off the shipping price too. The discount only applies to the item itself.

7.EE.2.stem: Two plans are given: Plan A costs 6n + 18, Plan B costs 3(2n + 6). What is true?
7.EE.2.explanation: Plan B expands to 6n + 18, exactly the same as Plan A.

choices.label: A
choices.misconception_text: Oops! If you look really closely at Plan B, you'll see it actually simplifies to be exactly the same as Plan A!

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. If you distribute that 3 in Plan B... surprise! It's identical to Plan A.

choices.label: C
choices.text: The plans are equivalent for all n

choices.label: D
choices.text: They are equal only when n = 0
choices.misconception_text: Careful! While they *are* equal at zero, they'll stay perfectly equal no matter what number you pick for n.

7.EE.2.stem: Which rewrite best shows the relationship between perimeter P and side s for a square plus 8 extra units: P = 4s + 8?
7.EE.2.explanation: Factoring 4 from 4s + 8 gives 4(s + 2), showing each side effectively has +2.

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Oops! Since it's a square, we have to make sure to count all four sides (4s) in the total.

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. It looks like the number of sides and the bonus units might have swapped places.

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful! If you multiply that out, you'd get 4s + 16, which is a bit different from our original rule!

7.EE.3.stem: The temperature was -3.5 degrees in the morning and rose by 7.2 degrees by noon. What was the noon temperature?

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Oops! It looks like the temperature moved the wrong way. Since it "rose" by 7.2, we should be adding to our starting number!

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. Since 7.2 is larger than 3.5, the final temperature should cross zero and end up on the positive side.

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful with the signs! It seems the starting negative sign was missed. Let's start at -3.5 and then add 7.2.

7.EE.3.stem: A hiker is at elevation 120 meters. They descend 3 times by 18.5 meters each. What is the final elevation?
7.EE.3.explanation: Total descent is 3 x 18.5 = 55.5. Final elevation = 120 - 55.5 = 64.5.

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Oops! To "descend" means you're going down. It looks like those steps were added to 120 instead of subtracted!

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Almost! It seems only one of the three descents was subtracted. Don't forget to account for all three of them.

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. While the number is right, the hiker is still high above sea level, so the final elevation should be a positive number.

7.EE.3.stem: A tank has 2 1/4 liters of water. You pour out 3/5 liter and then add 1/2 liter. How much water remains?

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Oops! It looks like both numbers were subtracted. Remember, the last step was *adding* water back into the tank!

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. It seems there was a tiny slip-up while finding a common denominator for those fractions.

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful with the order! It looks like the addition and subtraction steps might have gotten swapped.

7.EE.3.stem: A phone plan has a 12 dollar fee plus 0.08 dollars per minute. If the bill is 26.40 dollars, how many minutes were used?

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Oops! It looks like the $12 fee wasn't subtracted before dividing. We need to take that monthly fee out first!

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. It seems there might have been a little arithmetic error during the subtraction or the division step.

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful with the decimals! Dividing by a small number like 0.08 will actually give you a much larger answer than 14.4.

7.EE.3.stem: You estimate 19.8 / 0.5 to check reasonableness before exact work. Which estimate is best?
7.EE.3.explanation: Dividing by one-half is doubling. 19.8 doubles to about 39.6, so about 40.

choices.label: A
choices.misconception_text: Oops! Dividing by 0.5 (which is the same as one-half) actually makes a number *grow*! It's like asking how many halves fit into 20.

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. That would be the answer if we divided by 1, but since 0.5 is even smaller, our result will be larger.

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful with the decimal! Dividing by 0.5 is just like multiplying your original number by 2.

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Oops! You've got the subtraction down perfect, but remember that a negative number minus more positive numbers stays negative!

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. It seems 8 was added to -13. To get x alone, we'll need to *subtract* 8 from both sides instead.

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful! Take another look at the sign rules when you subtract a positive number from a negative total.

7.EE.4.explanation: Add 5 to both sides: 3x = 21. Divide by 3: x = 7.

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Oops! You did the first step perfectly by adding 5. Now, just don't forget to divide that result by 3!

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. After adding 5 to get 21, the final step is to divide by 3 to see what one single x is worth.

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful with the signs! Since 3x = 21 and both numbers are positive, our final x should also be positive.

7.EE.4.explanation: Subtract 4 from both sides: -2x = 6. Divide by -2: x = -3.

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. So close! You found that 2x should relate to 6, but remember that the coefficient is actually *-2*. We'll need to divide by -2 to get the right sign.

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Oops! Let's re-calculate that subtraction. 10 minus 4 should leave us with 6 before we move on to dividing.

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. It looks like x was added by mistake. Let's try to get that -2x term by itself first.

7.EE.4.explanation: Subtract 3 from both sides: 0.5x = 6. Divide by 0.5: x = 12.

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Oops! The subtraction was perfect (9 - 3 = 6). Now just remember that dividing 6 by 0.5 is exactly like doubling it!

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. We have to finish that subtraction (9 - 3) before we tackle the 0.5 multiplier.

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful! It seems some of the steps got a bit out of order. Let's follow the golden rule of equations: isolate x one step at a time!

7.EE.4.stem: A science quiz has 15 questions. A correct answer gives 2 points and a wrong answer loses 1 point. Kelly scored 21 points and answered every question. How many did she answer correctly?
7.EE.4.explanation: Let c be correct and w be wrong. c + w = 15 and 2c - w = 21. Substitute w = 15 - c: 2c - (15 - c) = 21, so 3c = 36 and c = 12.

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Oops! It seems the wrong answers were counted as zero. Don't forget that each miss *takes away* a point from the total!

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. If Kelly only got 9 correct, her score would be even lower once we subtract the points for the 6 she missed.

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful with the count! If she got 13 correct, her score would be 26 minus 2, which is close but not quite 21.

7.G.1.stem: A map uses a scale of 1:45,000. How long on the map is a road that is 900 meters in real life? (Give answer in cm.)
7.G.1.explanation: 900 m = 90,000 cm in real life. At 1:45,000 scale, map length = 90,000 รท 45,000 = 2 cm.

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Oops! It looks like one of the zeros might have slipped when converting meters to centimeters. Let's try that conversion one more time.

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. It seems there was an extra divide-by-ten. Dividing 90,000 by 45,000 should give us exactly 2!

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful! It's important to change the 900 meters into centimeters *before* you apply the map scale.

7.G.1.stem: A scale drawing uses 1 cm to represent 500 cm. If a segment is 7.2 cm on the drawing, what is the actual length in meters?
7.G.1.explanation: Actual length is 7.2 x 500 = 3600 cm. Convert to meters: 3600 cm = 36 m? Wait: 100 cm = 1 m, so 3600 cm = 36 m.

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Oops! It looks like an extra divide-by-10 happened when changing centimeters into meters. Let's re-verify that step.

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. Remember that 100 cm makes a meter. It looks like 1,000 was used for the conversion instead!

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful with the multiplier! We need to multiply our drawing size by the full 500 to find the actual real-world length.

7.G.1.stem: A segment is 6 cm long on a 1:20 scale drawing. The same real segment is redrawn at a 1:30 scale. What is the new drawing length?
7.G.1.explanation: At 1:20, 6 cm represents 120 cm actual. At 1:30, drawing length is 120 รท 30 = 4 cm.

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Oops! Since the new scale (1:30) is "smaller" than the old one, the drawing itself should shrink!

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. Scale problems work with multiplication and division, rather than just adding on the difference between the scale numbers.

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful! Let's find the real-life length first (120 cm) and then see how many 30-cm pieces fit into it!

7.G.1.stem: A rectangle on a drawing measures 3 cm by 5 cm at scale 1:100. What is its actual area in square meters?
7.G.1.explanation: Actual side lengths are 300 cm and 500 cm, which are 3 m and 5 m. Area = 3 x 5 = 15 m^2.

choices.label: A
choices.misconception_text: Oops! It looks like the scale was applied to the area only once. For area calculations, we have to scale *both* the length and the width!

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. It seems there was a tiny slip with the zeros when converting from cmยฒ to mยฒ.

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful with those zeros! Let's check the area again after we've changed each of the side lengths from centimeters to meters.

7.G.1.stem: Which scale produces the larger drawing of the same real object?
7.G.1.explanation: For the same real object, 1:80 gives a larger drawing than 1:120 because each 1 drawing unit represents less real distance.

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Oops! It's actually the other way: a smaller number on the bottom means each drawing unit represents *less* real space, which keeps the drawing larger!

choices.label: C
choices.text: Both produce the same drawing size
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. Different scale ratios will always results in different sized drawings for the same real item.

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful! We can definitely tell: the scale that reduces the object less (1:80) will always give you a bigger drawing.

7.G.2.stem: Can a triangle be constructed with angle measures 60 degrees, 60 degrees, and 60 degrees?
7.G.2.explanation: Angles determine the shape class; 60-60-60 gives equilateral triangles, scalable to many sizes.

choices.label: A
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. Actually, this is perfect! Since the angles add up exactly to 180 degrees, it forms a perfect equilateral triangle.

choices.label: B
choices.text: Exactly one shape type (equilateral), with many sizes

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. While you can only draw one *type* of shape (equilateral), you can make them in many different sizes!

choices.label: D
choices.text: Infinite triangles of unrelated angle types
choices.misconception_text: Careful! Since the angles are already fixed at 60-60-60, every triangle you draw will be a resized version of that same exact shape.

7.G.2.stem: Can a triangle be made with sides 2, 3, and 6?
7.G.2.explanation: 2 + 3 = 5, which is less than 6, so these sides cannot form a triangle.

choices.label: A
choices.misconception_text: Oops! Remember our "Triangle Rule": any two sides added up must be longer than the third side. Here, 2 + 3 is only 5, which is too short to reach across a side that is 6 long!

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. Any way you tilt them, these sides simply won't reach each other to close the shape.

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful! For a right triangle, the sides have to follow the rule aยฒ + bยฒ = cยฒ. These numbers don't quite fit that pattern!

7.G.2.stem: Given three side lengths 5, 5, and 8, how many non-congruent triangles are possible?
7.G.2.explanation: With three fixed side lengths that satisfy triangle inequality, SSS determines one congruent triangle.

choices.label: A
choices.misconception_text: Oops! This triangle *can* be built because any two sides (like 5 + 5) are longer than the third side (8)!

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. Once we have three fixed side lengths, there's only one way they can fit together into a triangle. Every version will be a twin of the first!

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful! If we only had the degrees, we could make many sizes. But since the lengths are set, the size is already locked in!

7.G.2.stem: You are given angles 40 degrees and 50 degrees and one side length. Which is true?
7.G.2.explanation: Angles are fixed (third is 90), and one side sets scale, so one unique triangle results.

choices.label: A
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. Actually, it's possible! Since we know two angles, the third one just has to be 90 degrees to reach our 180-degree goal!

choices.label: B
choices.text: Exactly one triangle size and shape is determined

choices.label: C
choices.text: Angles determine infinitely many unrelated shapes
choices.misconception_text: Not quite! Because we also have one fixed side length, it "anchors" the triangle so only one specific size can exist.

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful! With two angles and one side already chosen, there's only one way left to finish building the rest of the triangle.

7.G.2.stem: Which condition set guarantees a unique triangle?
7.G.2.explanation: Three valid side lengths (SSS) determine a unique triangle up to congruence.

choices.label: A
choices.misconception_text: Oops! This tells us the shape, but not the sizeโwe could draw a tiny version or a huge version and they'd both have those angles!

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. Just knowing one side length doesn't tell us how to tilt the other two sides or where they should meet up.

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful! Knowing one corner doesn't give us enough info about the other parts of the shape or how long the sides should be.

7.G.3.stem: A right rectangular prism is sliced parallel to its base. What shape is the cross-section?
7.G.3.explanation: A slice parallel to a rectangular base of a right prism gives a rectangle.

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Oops! If you cut a standard box parallel to the bottom, the slice will look exactly like a smaller version of the rectangular base!

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. Since a rectangular prism has only straight sides, a single flat cut will always result in a flat-edged shape like a rectangle.

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful! A rectangular prism doesn't have the right corners to create a 5-sided pentagon from a simple parallel cut.

7.G.3.stem: A right rectangular pyramid is sliced by a plane through the apex and midpoint of the base edge. Which section is most likely?
7.G.3.explanation: A plane through the apex and base region of a pyramid commonly forms a triangular cross-section.

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Oops! Any cut that starts at the very top point (the apex) and goes straight down will usually give you a triangular cross-section.

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. Since pyramids are made from flat triangular faces, any straight cut will have straight edges, not a curve like a circle.

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful! A 6-sided hexagon is much too complex for a single slice through the simple triangular point of a pyramid.

7.G.3.stem: Which cross-section cannot come from slicing a right rectangular prism?
7.G.3.explanation: Prism faces are flat polygons; planar sections are polygons, not circles.

choices.label: A
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. Actually, this is the most common result you'll see when slicing a box-like shape!

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. If you slice through the prism at an angle, you can definitely create a parallelogram shape.

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful! A square is just a special type of rectangle, so you'll see it any time you cut through a cube-like prism.

7.G.3.stem: A slice perpendicular to the base of a right rectangular prism and passing through two opposite top edges produces what kind of section?
7.G.3.explanation: For a right rectangular prism, such a vertical slice yields a rectangular cross-section.

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. This solid and this cut do not create curved boundaries.

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. A full through-cut of opposite edges in a prism gives four sides.

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful! You can get a trapezoid if you slice at an angle, but a slice perfectly parallel to the base will always be a rectangle.

7.G.3.stem: A right rectangular pyramid is sliced parallel to its base. Which description is correct?
7.G.3.explanation: A plane parallel to a pyramid's base gives a smaller similar copy of the base.

choices.label: A
choices.text: Cross-section is a smaller rectangle similar to the base

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. Slices parallel to a pyramid's base match the base shape.

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. Pyramid faces are polygonal.

choices.label: D
choices.text: Cross-section has no relation to the base
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. Parallel sections preserve shape type.

7.G.4.stem: A circular clock has diameter 40 cm. What is its area to the nearest ten square centimeters?
7.G.4.explanation: Radius is 20 cm. Area is pi x 20^2 = 400pi about 1256.6, which rounds to 1,260 cm^2.

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Oops! It looks like the whole diameter was used instead of the radius. Remember that radius is just *half* of the diameter!

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. It seems like the final area might have been cut in half by mistake. Let's try squaring that 20 cm radius first!

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful! That result looks more like circumference. For area, we need to use PI times the radius *squared*!

7.G.4.stem: Find the circumference of a circle with radius 7 cm. (Use pi = 22/7.)
7.G.4.explanation: Circumference is C = 2pi r = 2 x (22/7) x 7 = 44 cm.

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Oops! That value is actually the area of the circle. For circumference, we want 2 times PI times the radius!

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. It looks like the "2" was missed in our formula. Remember: Circumference = 2ฯr!

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful with those formulas! 14 is the diameter, but we still need to multiply it by PI to get the distance all the way around.

7.G.4.stem: A circle has circumference 31.4 cm. What is its diameter? (Use pi = 3.14.)
7.G.4.explanation: Since C = pi d, diameter is d = C/pi = 31.4/3.14 = 10 cm.

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Almost! 5 is the radius. The question specifically asks for the diameter, which is twice as long as the radius!

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. So close! It looks like there was a small rounding error during the work. 31.4 / 3.14 should give us exactly 10.

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful with that decimal point! When you divide 31.4 by 3.14, the answer is 10, not 100.

7.G.4.stem: Find the area of a circle with radius 3.5 cm. (Use pi = 22/7.)

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Oops! It looks like the radius squared (rยฒ) was missed. For area, we need to multiply PI by the radius *twice*!

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. It seems the diameter was squared instead of the radius. Let's stick with our 3.5 cm radius for the calculation.

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful! That result looks more like circumference. For area, we definitely want to use the ฯrยฒ formula!

7.G.4.stem: Which expression gives the area of a circle with diameter d?
7.G.4.explanation: Area uses radius squared: A = pi r^2. Since r = d/2, A = pi(d/2)^2.

choices.label: A
choices.misconception_text: Oops! That's the formula to find the distance *around* the circle (circumference). For the space *inside* (area), we need the radius squared!

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. We want to square only the radius, not the entire diameter. So we'll need to cut d in half before we square it.

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful with that extra "2"! The area formula is just PI times the radius squared.

7.G.5.stem: Two angles are complementary. One is 37 degrees. The other is:

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. It looks like you used supplementary instead of complementary.

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. Complementary angles do not have to be equal.

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. It looks like you subtracted from 100, not 90.

7.G.5.stem: Angles x and 112 degrees are supplementary. What is x?
7.G.5.explanation: Supplementary angles sum to 180, so x = 180 - 112 = 68.

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. It looks like you subtracted from 90 instead of 180.

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. It looks like you assumed supplementary means equal.

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. It looks like you added instead of finding missing angle.

7.G.5.stem: Vertical angles are labeled (3x + 5) degrees and (5x - 19) degrees. Find x.
7.G.5.explanation: Vertical angles are equal: 3x + 5 = 5x - 19. So 24 = 2x and x = 12.

choices.label: A
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. It looks like you solved with arithmetic error.

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. It looks like you may have subtracted constants incorrectly.

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. It looks like you doubled the correct value.

7.G.5.stem: Adjacent angles form a straight line and are (2y + 10) degrees and (y - 4) degrees. Find y.
7.G.5.explanation: Straight line gives supplementary angles: (2y + 10) + (y - 4) = 180. Then 3y + 6 = 180, so y = 58.

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. It looks like you likely made a subtraction error after combining terms.

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. It looks like you likely added constants with the wrong sign.

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful! Let's set up the equation: (x + 10) + 40 = 90. Solving that will lead us to the right x!

7.G.5.stem: If one angle is 4x and its adjacent supplementary angle is 2x + 30, what is the smaller angle measure?
7.G.5.explanation: 4x + (2x + 30) = 180 gives 6x = 150, so x = 25. Angles are 100 and 80, so the smaller angle is 80 degrees.

choices.label: A
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. It looks like you solved the linear equation with an arithmetic error.

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. It looks like you chose the larger supplementary angle.

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. It looks like you treated 2x + 30 as if x were 0.

7.G.6.stem: Find area of a triangle with base 10 and height 7.
7.G.6.explanation: Triangle area is 1/2 x base x height = 1/2 x 10 x 7 = 35.

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Oops! 70 is the area of a rectangle. Since this is a triangle, we need to take exactly half of that!

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. It seems the base and height were added. For area, we want to use multiplication instead!

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful! It looks like there was a little slip in the math. Let's try 10 times 7, then cut that in half.

7.G.6.stem: A prism has l = 5, w = 4, h = 3. What is its volume?
7.G.6.explanation: Volume of right rectangular prism is lwh = 5 x 4 x 3 = 60.

choices.label: A
choices.misconception_text: Oops! Only two of the numbers were multiplied. To find the volume of a box, we need to multiply all three!

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Not quite! It seems some calculations from surface area might have gotten mixed in here!

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful! It looks like the volume might have been doubled. 5 x 4 x 3 should give us 60.

7.G.6.stem: What is the surface area of a cube with side length 6?

choices.label: A
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. It looks like you found area of one face only.

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. It looks like you used two faces instead of six.

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. It looks like you used an incorrect formula.

7.G.6.stem: A composite figure is made from two non-overlapping rectangles with areas 24 and 18. What is total area?
7.G.6.explanation: For non-overlapping parts, total area is sum of part areas: 24 + 18 = 42.

choices.label: A
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. It looks like you subtracted areas instead of adding.

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. It looks like you multiplied instead of summing parts.

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. It looks like you counted only one part.

7.G.6.stem: A right prism has base area 12.5 square units and height 8 units. What is volume?
7.G.6.explanation: Volume = base area x height = 12.5 x 8 = 100.

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. It looks like you added base area and height.

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. It looks like you subtracted instead of multiplying.

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. It looks like you used a nearby product with arithmetic error.

7.NS.2.explanation: Multiply absolute values: 4 x 3 = 12. A negative times a positive is negative, so the result is -12.

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Oops! You multiplied 4 and 3 perfectly, but remember our rule: when multiplying a negative and a positive, the result is always negative!

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. It looks like 4 and 3 might have been subtracted. Let's try 4 times 3 again!

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful! It seems 4 and 3 were added up. Since we're multiplying, we want to find the total product.

7.NS.2.explanation: Multiply numerators and denominators: (-2 x -9)/(3 x 4) = 18/12 = 3/2.

choices.label: A
choices.misconception_text: Oops! You simplified the fractions very well, but remember that a negative times a negative will always result in a positive answer!

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. It looks like you're almost there! 18/12 is the right math, but simplified it down to its smallest form will make it a perfect final answer.

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. It looks like division was used by mistake. In multiplication, we multiply straight across: top x top and bottom x bottom.

7.NS.2.explanation: 15 divided by 3 is 5. Since the signs are different, the quotient is negative: -5.

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Oops! You found that 15 divided by 3 is 5, but because the signs are different, the final result must be negative.

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. It seems multiplication was used. For 15 divided by -3, we want to see how many times -3 fits into 15!

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful! It looks like 3 was subtracted from 15. In division, we're trying to share 15 into 3 equal (but negative) groups.

7.NS.2.explanation: 1.8 รท 0.6 = 3. One number is negative and the other is positive, so the quotient is -3.

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Oops! 1.8 divided by 0.6 is indeed 3, but since the first number is negative, our final answer should be -3.

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. It looks like subtraction was used. For dividing, we're finding how many 0.6 size "scoops" fit into 1.8!

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful with the decimals! When we divide 1.8 by a small part like 0.6, the result actually turns out larger than 1!

7.NS.2.explanation: For multiplication and division, same signs give positive, different signs give negative. So positive divided by negative is negative.

choices.label: A
choices.text: A negative divided by a negative is always negative.
choices.misconception_text: Oops! Remember our "matching twins" rule: if both signs are negative, they combine to make a positive result!

choices.label: B
choices.text: A negative multiplied by a positive is always positive.
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. If the signs are different, the result will always be negative.

choices.label: C
choices.text: A positive divided by a negative is always negative.

choices.label: D
choices.text: A positive multiplied by a positive is always negative.
choices.misconception_text: Careful! Two positives will always stay positive. A negative can only appear if at least one of the numbers is negative.

7.NS.3.stem: The temperature is -3 deg C in the morning and rises by 8 deg C by noon. What is the noon temperature?
7.NS.3.explanation: Start at -3 and add 8: -3 + 8 = 5, so the noon temperature is 5 deg C.

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Oops! It looks like the temperature moved down. Since it "rose" by 8, we should add that 8 to our starting -3.

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. Since 8 is larger than 3, the temperature moves all the way past zero and into the positive territory!

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful with those negatives! It seems both numbers were added as positives. Remember we started down at -3 before it got warmer.

7.NS.3.stem: Aiden owes $21. He pays $15, spends $35, then pays $50. What is his final balance?
7.NS.3.explanation: Use signed numbers: -21 + 15 - 35 + 50 = 9. A positive result means a $9 credit.

choices.label: A
choices.misconception_text: Oops! It looks like you found the final amount, but Aiden actually has a positive balance now since he paid back so much!

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. Let's try combining all the payments and debts one more timeโadding what he pays and subtracting what he spends.

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Close! It seems there might have been a small error during the math. Let's double-check the total balance again!

7.NS.3.stem: A recipe uses 3/4 cup sugar per batch. How much sugar is needed for 2 1/2 batches?

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. It looks like you added 3/4 and 2 1/2 instead of multiplying per-batch amount by number of batches.

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. It looks like you multiplied numerators and denominators but did not simplify correctly.

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. It looks like you likely multiplied one factor incorrectly after converting the mixed number.

7.NS.3.explanation: 12.6 รท 3 = 4.2. Since the signs are different, the result is -4.2.

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. It looks like you divided correctly but ignored the sign rule for positive divided by negative.

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. It looks like you subtracted instead of dividing.

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. It looks like you misplaced the decimal point by treating 12.6 as 126.

choices.label: A
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. It looks like you added first and then multiplied, ignoring order of operations.

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. It looks like you used multiplication first but lost a negative sign.

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. It looks like you multiplied and added absolute values while ignoring both negative signs.

7.RP.1.stem: A cyclist rides 3/4 mile in 1/2 hour. What is the unit rate in miles per hour?
7.RP.1.explanation: Unit rate means per 1 hour: (3/4) รท (1/2) = (3/4) x 2 = 3/2 = 1 1/2 mph.

choices.label: A
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. It looks like you multiplied the fractions instead of dividing distance by time.

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. It looks like you reversed the ratio and divided time by distance.

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. It looks like you added the fractions instead of computing a rate.

7.RP.1.stem: 5/6 kilogram of nuts costs $4.50. What is the cost per kilogram?
7.RP.1.explanation: Cost per kilogram is 4.50 รท (5/6) = 4.50 x (6/5) = 5.40.

choices.label: A
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. It looks like you multiplied 4.50 by 5/6 instead of dividing by 5/6.

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. It looks like you used an incorrect decimal conversion while scaling to one kilogram.

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. It looks like you treated 5/6 as 0.6 and divided by the wrong value.

7.RP.1.stem: A recipe uses 7/8 cup sugar for 14 cookies. How much sugar is used per cookie?
7.RP.1.explanation: Per cookie means divide by 14: (7/8) รท 14 = 7/(8 x 14) = 7/112 = 1/16 cup.

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. It looks like you simplified the numerator and denominator without dividing by the total number of cookies.

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. It looks like you ignored the denominator in 7/8 and used only 7 as the total sugar amount.

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. It looks like you multiplied denominators but did not simplify the fraction rate.

7.RP.1.stem: A faucet runs 2 1/4 liters in 3 minutes. What is the unit rate in liters per minute?
7.RP.1.explanation: Convert 2 1/4 to 2.25 liters. Then divide by 3 minutes: 2.25 รท 3 = 0.75 liters per minute.

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Oops! It looks like the division might have been done in reverse. To find liters per minute, we'll want to divide the total liters by the number of minutes!

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. It seems multiplication was used instead of division. Let's try dividing that 2.25 liters by 3 to find out how much flows in just one minute.

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful with the units! 2.25 is the total for all 3 minutes combined. We're looking for the unit rate, which is the amount for exactly 1 minute.

7.RP.1.stem: What is the unit rate of 9/10 meter in 3/5 second?
7.RP.1.explanation: Unit rate is (9/10) รท (3/5) = (9/10) x (5/3) = 45/30 = 3/2 meters per second.

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Oops! It looks like the two fractions were multiplied. To find the unit rate (meters per second), we'll need to divide the distance by the time!

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. It seems the ratio was flipped upside down. Let's make sure we're dividing the meters by the seconds to get the right speed!

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful! It looks like there was a small error when flipping and multiplying that second fraction. Let's try it again step-by-step.

7.RP.2.stem: In a table, x values are 2, 4, 6 and y values are 5, 10, 15. What is the constant of proportionality k in y = kx?
7.RP.2.explanation: For proportional relationships, k = y/x. Using any row: 5/2 = 2.5, 10/4 = 2.5, 15/6 = 2.5.

choices.label: A
choices.misconception_text: Oops! It looks like you found the difference between the numbers. For proportional relationships, we use the ratio of y to x instead!

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. 5 is the first y-value on the table, but we need to see how it relates to its corresponding x-value, which is 2.

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful with the order! It seems the ratio was flipped (x/y). Let's try dividing y by x to find the constant k.

7.RP.2.stem: A proportional relationship passes through the point (3, 12). Which equation represents it?
7.RP.2.explanation: k = y/x = 12/3 = 4, so the proportional equation is y = 4x.

choices.label: A
choices.misconception_text: Oops! It looks like the x-value (3) was used as the constant. Let's find k by dividing the y-value by the x-value (12 divided by 3)!

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. While 3 + 9 does equal 12, proportional equations always follow the pattern y = kx, with no extra numbers added or subtracted.

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful! 12 is the y-value for this specific point, but we're looking for the constant multiplier k that connects x to y.

7.RP.2.stem: Which table does NOT show a proportional relationship?
7.RP.2.explanation: In a proportional relationship, y/x must be constant. For option C: 3/1 = 3, 7/2 = 3.5, 11/3 is not the same.

choices.label: A
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. Actually, this one *is* proportional! If you divide y by x in every row, you'll see you get the same answer of 4 every single time.

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. This one is also proportional because the ratio of y to x stays constant at 3 for every pair of numbers.

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful! Even with these smaller numbers, the relationship is proportional since the ratio of y to x is always 0.4.

7.RP.2.stem: A graph represents y = 3.5x. Which point must be on the graph?
7.RP.2.explanation: Substitute x = 2 into y = 3.5x: y = 7. So (2, 7) is on the graph.

choices.label: A
choices.misconception_text: Oops! Remember that all proportional graphs must pass through the origin (0, 0). If x is zero, then y must be zero too!

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Almost! It looks like there was a small slip with the multiplication. Let's try 3.5 times 2 again!

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful with the coordinates! It seems the x and y values were swapped. Let's plug 2 in for x and see what y equals.

7.RP.2.stem: If y is proportional to x and y = 14 when x = 4, what is y when x = 10?

choices.label: A
choices.misconception_text: Oops! It looks like 6 was added to both x and y. In proportional problems, we want to find the multiplier rather than just adding!

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. 28 would be the answer if x had doubled, but x went from 4 to 10. Finding the constant k (y/x) first will help.

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful! Multiplying 10 by 14 is a big jump. Let's see how y relates to its original x (4) first to find the scaling factor.

7.SP.1.stem: A school wants to estimate the average homework time for all students. Which sample is most representative?
7.SP.1.explanation: A random sample from all grades is most likely to represent the whole school population.

choices.label: A
choices.text: Ask only students in the advanced math club.
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. This is a biased subgroup and not representative of all students.

choices.label: B
choices.text: Randomly select students from all grade levels in the school.

choices.label: C
choices.text: Ask the first 20 students who arrive early.
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. It looks like you convenience samples can overrepresent specific behaviors.

choices.label: D
choices.text: Ask only students who volunteer online.
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. It looks like you volunteer samples can bias results toward students with stronger opinions.

7.SP.1.stem: Which situation is most likely to produce a biased sample?
7.SP.1.explanation: Only surveying students in one place/time can miss parts of the population and create bias.

choices.label: A
choices.text: Choosing every 10th name from an alphabetized list.
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. It looks like you systematic sampling can still be representative if the list has no harmful pattern.

choices.label: B
choices.text: Surveying only students in the cafeteria line at lunch.

choices.label: C
choices.text: Using random number generator to pick IDs.
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. This is generally an unbiased random method.

choices.label: D
choices.text: Sampling students from each grade proportionally.
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. It looks like you stratified sampling by grade is often used to improve representativeness.

7.SP.1.stem: A random sample of 60 students is taken from a school of 900 students. Which conclusion is valid?
7.SP.1.explanation: Representative random samples are used to make estimates about populations.

choices.label: A
choices.text: You can never use a sample to learn about a population.
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. It looks like you statistics is specifically used to infer population characteristics from samples.

choices.label: B
choices.text: The sample can be used to estimate the population if it is representative.

choices.label: C
choices.text: The sample gives exact values for every student.
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. It looks like you samples provide estimates, not exact information for each individual.

choices.label: D
choices.text: A sample smaller than 100 is always invalid.
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. It looks like you validity depends on sampling method and context, not a fixed sample-size cutoff.

7.SP.1.stem: Two random samples are used to estimate average sleep time: Sample A has 20 students and Sample B has 200 students. Which is usually more reliable?
7.SP.1.explanation: Larger random samples typically reduce variability and improve estimate reliability.

choices.label: A
choices.text: Sample A, because smaller samples are always better.
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. It looks like you smaller random samples usually have more variability.

choices.label: B
choices.text: Sample B, because larger random samples usually give more stable estimates.

choices.label: C
choices.text: Both are exactly equally reliable in all cases.
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. It looks like you larger random samples generally reduce sampling error.

choices.label: D
choices.text: Neither can ever estimate population sleep time.
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. It looks like you samples can provide useful estimates when collected appropriately.

7.SP.1.stem: A town wants to estimate support for a new park. A survey is sent only to families who already use the current park. Why is this a problem?
7.SP.1.explanation: Sampling only current park users excludes other residents and likely inflates support estimates.

choices.label: A
choices.text: It is random because park users are easy to identify.
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. It looks like you ease of sampling does not make a sample random or representative.

choices.label: B
choices.text: It overrepresents people likely to favor parks, so the sample is biased.

choices.label: C
choices.text: It is unbiased because park users are part of the population.
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. It looks like you using only one subgroup can still bias the estimate.

choices.label: D
choices.text: It is valid only if exactly 100 families are surveyed.
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. It looks like you sample size alone does not fix selection bias.

7.SP.2.stem: In a random sample of 50 students, 18 prefer biking to school. About how many out of 400 students would you expect to prefer biking?
7.SP.2.explanation: Sample proportion is 18/50 = 0.36. Estimated count for 400 is 0.36 x 400 = 144.

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. It looks like you scaled to 200 students instead of 400.

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. It looks like you used 18/40 instead of 18/50 when finding the sample proportion.

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. It looks like you treated 18 as 45% instead of 36%.

7.SP.2.stem: A random sample of 20 light bulbs has 3 defective bulbs. Estimate the number of defective bulbs in a shipment of 500.
7.SP.2.explanation: Defective rate is 3/20 = 0.15. Estimated defective bulbs: 0.15 x 500 = 75.

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. It looks like you doubled the estimate by treating 3/20 as 30%.

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. It looks like you used 3/25 instead of 3/20 when scaling.

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. It looks like you used the sample count directly without scaling to the full shipment.

7.SP.2.stem: Two random samples of equal size from the same population produce estimates 42% and 47%. What is the best interpretation?
7.SP.2.explanation: Random sampling produces variation. Different samples can give different but still reasonable estimates.

choices.label: A
choices.text: At least one sample must be invalid because estimates are different.
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. It looks like you different random samples can naturally produce slightly different estimates.

choices.label: B
choices.text: Sampling variability can cause different estimates from different random samples.

choices.label: C
choices.text: The population percentage is exactly the average, 44.5%.
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. It looks like you the true population value is unknown; sample averages do not guarantee exactness.

choices.label: D
choices.text: The larger estimate is always the true population value.
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. It looks like you a larger sample estimate is not automatically more accurate.

7.SP.2.stem: Why might a researcher generate multiple random samples of the same size?
7.SP.2.explanation: Multiple samples help measure sampling variability and how stable estimates are.

choices.label: A
choices.text: To eliminate all variation so every estimate is identical.
choices.misconception_text: Oops! It's actually impossible to get rid of all variation in the real world. Multiple samples help us *understand* those differences, rather than making them go away!

choices.label: B
choices.text: To understand how much estimates can vary due to random sampling.

choices.label: C
choices.text: Because one random sample can never be used for inference.
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. One good random sample is actually very helpful! But having more than one helps us see how much the results might fluctuate from group to group.

choices.label: D
choices.text: To guarantee the true population value is found exactly.
choices.misconception_text: Careful with your expectations! Samples give us amazing "ballpark" estimates, but they rarely give us the 100% exact number for the whole population.

7.SP.2.stem: A random sample finds that 64% of households recycle weekly. Predict approximately how many of 2,500 households recycle weekly.

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Oops! It looks like you calculated for 1,000 households instead. Multiplication between 0.64 and the full 2,500 will give us the right total!

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. It seems you might have found the number of households that *don't* recycle instead. Let's stick with the recyclable group!

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful! That's exactly 50% of the households. Our survey says the number is a bit higherโcloser to 64%!

7.SP.3.stem: Two data sets have similar spread. Set A center is 42, set B center is 46, and typical variability measure is 2. The center difference is how many variability units?
7.SP.3.explanation: Center difference is 46 - 42 = 4. Divide by variability 2 to get 2 variability units.

choices.label: A
choices.misconception_text: Oops! It looks like only part of the difference was used. The total gap between the centers is 4, which is exactly *two* units of 2!

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. 4 is the raw difference between the numbers. We want to see how many "units of 2" (our variability measure) that 4 represents.

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful! It seems like the numbers were multiplied. To find out "how many units," we should divide the gap by the variability measure!

7.SP.3.stem: If two dot plots have large visual overlap and similar variability, what is a reasonable conclusion?
7.SP.3.explanation: Large overlap usually means the center difference is small compared to variability.

choices.label: A
choices.misconception_text: Oops! Even if they look very similar, it doesn't mean every single data point is exactly the same in both groups. There can still be small differences!

choices.label: B
choices.text: Any center difference is likely small relative to spread

choices.label: C
choices.text: Centers must differ by at least 5 spread units
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. If the centers were that far apart, the two groups wouldn't overlap much at allโthey'd be grouped on opposite ends!

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful! If variability were zero, every single dot would be in one exact stack. Overlap just means the groups are mixed together.

7.SP.3.stem: Set A and B each have MAD about 3. Their medians are 18 and 27. How many MADs apart are the centers?
7.SP.3.explanation: Median difference is 27 - 18 = 9. With MAD 3, that is 9/3 = 3 MADs.

choices.label: A
choices.misconception_text: Oops! The total gap between 18 and 27 is 9. Since each MAD is 3 units, we need to see how many times 3 goes into 9!

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. It seems the division was slightly off. 9 divided by 3 should give us a whole number result!

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful! 9 is the raw difference between the medians. We want to express that difference in "MAD units" instead.

7.SP.3.stem: Which situation suggests less overlap between two similarly spread distributions?
7.SP.3.explanation: Larger center separation in spread units generally means less visual overlap.

choices.label: A
choices.misconception_text: Oops! When the centers are that close (only half a MAD away), the two groups will be very bundled together with a lot of overlap!

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. With only 1 MAD of difference, the groups will still be quite mixed in the center.

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful! If the centers have zero difference, the groups are sitting right on top of each other with the *most* possible overlap!

7.SP.3.stem: Two groups have similar variability. Group X center is 64, Group Y center is 58, variability measure is 2 for both. Best interpretation?
7.SP.3.explanation: Difference is 64 - 58 = 6. Divide by 2 gives 3 variability units.

choices.label: A
choices.text: Groups differ by 3 variability units, so centers are substantially separated

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Oops! 6 is the raw difference between the numbers. To find the "variability units," we divide that 6 by the scale factor of 2!

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. Let's re-calculate: 64 minus 58 is 6. How many units of 2 fit into that 6?

choices.label: D
choices.text: Groups cannot be compared without exact same data values
choices.misconception_text: Careful! We can actually learn a lot just by comparing the centers and the spread, even without seeing every individual number.

7.SP.4.stem: Sample A and B are random samples from two schools. Mean test scores are 78 and 85, with similar spread. Best inference?
7.SP.4.explanation: With random samples and similar variability, a higher sample mean suggests a higher population center.

choices.label: A
choices.text: School B likely has higher average score than School A

choices.label: B
choices.text: Schools must have exactly identical populations
choices.misconception_text: Oops! Since the sample scores are quite different (78 vs 85), it's more likely that the schools' overall scores are different too!

choices.label: C
choices.text: No inference is possible from random samples
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. Making these kinds of "likely" predictions is exactly what random samples are for!

choices.label: D
choices.text: School A is definitely better with certainty
choices.misconception_text: Careful! School A's score of 78 is actually lower than 85, so it's reaching a different conclusion than what the data shows.

7.SP.4.stem: Two samples have the same mean, but Sample X has much larger variability. What is reasonable?
7.SP.4.explanation: Equal centers suggest similar typical value, while different spread suggests different consistency.

choices.label: A
choices.text: Centers look similar, but consistency differs

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Oops! The question tells us the means are the same. It's the "spread" (variability) that is really different between the two groups.

choices.label: C
choices.text: Variability has no effect on inference
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. Variability is super important because it tells us if the data is predictable or all over the place!

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful! "Larger variability" actually means Sample X is *more* spread out than Sample Y is.

7.SP.4.stem: Sample medians are 14 and 16, with large overlap and high variability in both groups. Best conclusion?
7.SP.4.explanation: When overlap is large relative to center difference, only cautious inference is reasonable.

choices.label: A
choices.text: There may be only a small population difference, if any

choices.label: B
choices.text: Population 2 is certainly much larger in center
choices.misconception_text: Oops! Because the groups overlap so much and are so spread out, we can't be "certain" about a large difference based on such a small gap.

choices.label: C
choices.text: Population 1 must be larger because 14 is smaller
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. 14 is actually the smaller number here. But even then, the high overlap makes it hard to be sure about anything.

choices.label: D
choices.text: Random samples cannot be used for inference
choices.misconception_text: Careful! We CAN use them to make a cautious guess, but the data here tells us the difference is likely very subtle.

7.SP.4.stem: Which condition makes a comparative inference stronger?
7.SP.4.explanation: Large center separation with low spread gives clearer group differences.

choices.label: A
choices.text: Centers far apart and variability small

choices.label: B
choices.text: Centers very close and variability large
choices.misconception_text: Oops! If the centers are close and the groups are all spread out, it's very hard to tell them apart. That makes our inference weaker!

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Not quite! Random samples are always the most reliable way for making a strong, credible inference.

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful! We always need to account for variability because it tells us how much we can trust that the center value is truly "typical."

7.SP.4.stem: Sample A has mean 52 and MAD 2. Sample B has mean 55 and MAD 8. Which inference is best?
7.SP.4.explanation: B's mean is larger (55 vs 52), but B is less consistent due to higher MAD.

choices.label: A
choices.text: B has a higher center but much greater spread

choices.label: B
choices.text: A has higher center and greater spread
choices.misconception_text: Oops! It looks like our labels were swapped. B has the higher mean (55) and the larger MAD (8), which means it's more spread out!

choices.label: C
choices.text: The samples must come from identical populations
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. Since both the centers and the variability are quite different, it's very likely these are two distinct groups.

choices.label: D
choices.text: MAD does not matter for inference
choices.misconception_text: Careful! The MAD is what tells us that B is much less "consistent" or predictable than A.

7.SP.5.stem: A spinner has 8 equal sections. 2 are red, 3 are blue, and 3 are green. What is P(red)?
7.SP.5.explanation: Probability is favorable outcomes over total outcomes: 2/8 = 1/4.

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Oops! It looks like red was compared only to the other colors. Remember: probability is red sections out of the *total* number of slots (2 out of 8)!

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. We have two red sections, so the top of our fraction should be a 2 instead of a 1.

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful! Probability must always be between 0 and 1. 2 is the count of red sections, but we need the fraction!

7.SP.5.stem: Which value cannot be a probability?
7.SP.5.explanation: Probabilities must be between 0 and 1 inclusive. So 1.4 is not possible.

choices.label: A
choices.misconception_text: Nice try. Actually, 0 *is* a valid probability! It just means an event is "impossible," like rolling a 7 on a standard die.

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. Since 0.62 is between 0 and 1, it's a perfectly fine probability.

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Careful! 1 is the highest valid probability possible. It means an event is "100% ciertos" to happen!

7.SP.5.explanation: Convert 3/5 to 0.6. Since 0.72 > 0.6, Event A is more likely.

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Oops! 3/5 is the same as 0.60. Since 0.60 is smaller than 0.72, Event B is actually less likely.

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. When we turn 3/5 into a decimal (0.60), we can see it's quite a bit smaller than 0.72.

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful! We have all the numbers we needโit's just easiest to compare them when they are both written as decimals!

7.SP.5.stem: A probability of 0.03 is best described as:
7.SP.5.explanation: 0.03 is very close to 0, so the event is unlikely.

choices.label: A
choices.misconception_text: Oops! A "likely" event usually has a probability close to 1 (like 0.90). 0.03 is very close to zero!

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. That description is usually for probabilities around 0.50. 0.03 is extremely small.

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful! A "certain" event always has a probability of exactly 1. 0.03 means it's a very rare occurrence!

7.SP.5.stem: If P(rain tomorrow) = 0.28, what is P(no rain tomorrow)?
7.SP.5.explanation: An event and its complement add to 1. So P(no rain) = 1 - 0.28 = 0.72.

choices.label: A
choices.misconception_text: Oops! 0.28 is the chance that it *will* rain. We're looking for the opposite: the part that fits into 100% total!

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. Probabilities can never go above 1. To find the opposite, we should subtract 0.28 *from* 1.

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful! While we never know for sure, we can use the exact 0.28 chance to calculate the exact opposite chance of 0.72.

7.SP.6.stem: A coin is tossed 100 times and lands heads 52 times. What is the experimental probability of heads?
7.SP.6.explanation: Experimental probability is favorable outcomes over total outcomes: 52/100 = 0.52.

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Oops! 0.48 is the experimental probability of tails! We're looking for the heads count this time.

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. 52 is how many times it happened, but probability needs to be written as "52 out of 100" or 0.52.

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful with labels! 52 out of 100 is 0.52, not 5.2. Remember, experimental probabilities always stay between 0 and 1!

7.SP.6.stem: A spinner lands on red 18 times in 60 spins. What is the experimental probability of red?

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Oops! 0.70 is the probability of *not* landing on red. We're looking for the red result here.

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. It looks like it was calculated as if there were 100 spins. Let's try 18 divided by 60 instead!

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful! It seems the division was done backwards. We want the successes (18) divided by the total number of tries (60).

7.SP.6.stem: As the number of trials in a random experiment increases, experimental probability usually:
7.SP.6.explanation: In the long run, relative frequency tends to approach the theoretical probability.

choices.label: A
choices.text: Moves farther away from theoretical probability.
choices.misconception_text: Oops! It's actually the opposite: the more we try it, the more the "randomness" evens out and starts to look like the math theory!

choices.label: B
choices.text: Becomes exactly equal to theoretical probability after 10 trials.
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. 10 trials is still a very small group. We need many more shots for the results to match the theory perfectly.

choices.label: C
choices.text: Tends to get closer to theoretical probability.

choices.label: D
choices.text: Has no relationship to theoretical probability.
choices.misconception_text: Careful! They are tied together. Experimental results are our best way to *check* if our theoretical model is actually working!

7.SP.6.stem: If the probability of an event is 0.35, about how many times should it occur in 200 trials?
7.SP.6.explanation: Expected relative frequency is probability x number of trials: 0.35 x 200 = 70.

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Oops! 35 would be right if there were only 100 trials. Since we have 200, we need to double that expectation!

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. 130 is the number of times we expect the event *won't* happen. Let's find the 0.35 part instead.

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful! It looks like there was a small error in the calculation. Let's try 0.35 times 200 one more time.

7.SP.6.stem: Two students estimate P(heads) for a fair coin. Student A tosses 20 times and gets 0.60. Student B tosses 400 times and gets 0.51. Which estimate is generally more reliable?
7.SP.6.explanation: Larger trial counts generally produce more stable relative frequencies, so Student B's estimate is typically more reliable.

choices.label: A
choices.text: Student A, because 0.60 is farther from 0.5.
choices.misconception_text: Oops! Just being further away doesn't mean it's better. Student A might have just had a short lucky streak of extra heads!

choices.label: B
choices.text: Student B, because more trials usually reduce random fluctuation.

choices.label: C
choices.text: Both are equally reliable because both used random tosses.
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. While both procedures were correct, a much larger number of trials (400 vs 20) makes the result much more trustworthy.

choices.label: D
choices.text: Neither is useful because experimental probability cannot estimate true probability.
choices.misconception_text: Careful! Experimental results are a fantastic way to estimate the truthโespecially when you do a lot of trials like Student B did!

7.SP.7.stem: A fair die is rolled once. Model probability of rolling 5 is:
7.SP.7.explanation: One favorable face out of six equally likely outcomes gives 1/6.

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Oops! A standard die has *six* sides, so the total on the bottom of our fraction must be a 6!

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. 5/6 is the probability of rolling *anything except* a five. We're looking just for the five!

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful! 1/2 is the probability of rolling something like an even or odd number. For one specific side, it's 1 out of 6.

7.SP.7.stem: A bag has 3 red and 2 blue marbles. Model probability of drawing red is:
7.SP.7.explanation: There are 5 total marbles and 3 favorable red marbles, so probability is 3/5.

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Oops! 2/5 is the probability for choosing a blue marble. The question asks for red instead!

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. Probability can never be larger than 1! Let's put the red count (3) over the total count (5).

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful! Since there are three different red marbles to pick, you have three chances to get one, not just one.

7.SP.7.stem: A spinner model predicts P(green)=0.25. In 20 spins, green appears 9 times. Which is the best explanation of the difference?
7.SP.7.explanation: Expected count is 0.25 x 20 = 5, but random variation can produce different short-run results like 9.

choices.label: A
