choices.text: The model must be wrong in every case
choices.misconception_text: Oops! Just because the result didn't match perfectly this once doesn't mean the whole model is broken. It could just be a lucky streak!

choices.label: B
choices.text: Random variation in a small number of trials

choices.label: C
choices.text: Probability guarantees exact outcomes every time
choices.misconception_text: Not quite! Probability tells us what to expect over the "long run," but short-run results can be very unpredictable.

choices.label: D
choices.text: Green is impossible on this spinner
choices.misconception_text: Careful! Since we actually saw green happen 9 times, we know it's definitely possible!

7.SP.7.stem: A model predicts heads with probability 0.5. In 1000 tosses, 502 heads occur. Best conclusion?
7.SP.7.explanation: 502/1000 = 0.502, which is very close to 0.5, so this supports the model.

choices.label: A
choices.text: Observed frequency is reasonably consistent with the model

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Oops! 502 out of 1000 is still extremely close to one-half. A small difference like that is just a normal part of random chance.

choices.label: C
choices.text: Model probability should be changed to 0.502 exactly
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. We don't have to rewrite the rules after just one experiment. Our results show the "fair coin" model is still very reliable!

choices.label: D
choices.text: No probability model can be used for coins
choices.misconception_text: Careful! Coins are actually the perfect example for learning about how probability models work.

7.SP.7.stem: A game claims win probability 0.7. You observe 21 wins in 50 games. Which statement is most reasonable?
7.SP.7.explanation: Observed frequency 21/50 = 0.42 is much lower than 0.7, suggesting possible model mismatch or non-random effects.

choices.label: A
choices.text: Observed 0.42 is far below 0.7, so investigate model assumptions and game fairness

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Oops! 0.42 and 0.70 are quite different. When the gap is that big, it usually means the model might not be right!

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. In fact, our experimental data (21/50) actually suggests the game might not be as easy to win as it claims.

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful! They are super usefulโthey are what allowed us to spot that this game might be hiding something!

7.SP.8.stem: Two fair coins are tossed. What is P(exactly one head)?
7.SP.8.explanation: Outcomes are HH, HT, TH, TT. Exactly one head is HT or TH: 2 out of 4 = 1/2.

choices.label: A
choices.misconception_text: Oops! There are actually two ways to get one head: HT or TH. That gives us 2 chances out of 4 total!

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. 3/4 is the chance for "at least one head." We're looking for ONLY one head!

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful! With two coins, there are four possible outcomes (HH, HT, TH, TT) to count as our "whole" total.

7.SP.8.stem: A fair die is rolled and a fair coin is tossed. What is P(rolling an even number and getting heads)?
7.SP.8.explanation: P(even)=3/6=1/2 and P(heads)=1/2. Multiply independent events: 1/2 x 1/2 = 1/4.

choices.label: A
choices.misconception_text: Oops! That might be the chance for just one event. Don't forget we're combining both the die roll AND the coin toss together!

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. Think of it like this: half our die results are even (1/2), and half of those will also have heads (1/2). Half of a half is 1/4!

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful with the counts! There are 3 even numbers (2, 4, 6) on the die. So we have 3 winning outcomes out of 12 total possibilities.

7.SP.8.stem: A bag has 3 red and 2 blue marbles. Two marbles are drawn without replacement. What is P(both red)?
7.SP.8.explanation: First red is 3/5, then red is 2/4. Product is 6/20 = 3/10.

choices.label: A
choices.misconception_text: Oops! It looks like you assumed the first marble was put back. Since it stayed out, there are fewer red marbles left for the next pick!

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. Don't forget that after you take one out, the bag only has 4 marbles left in total for the second draw!

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful! That estimate is a bit higher than the actual math. Let's try 3/5 times 2/4 to find the exact answer!

7.SP.8.stem: Spinner A has 4 equal sectors with 1 green. Spinner B has 5 equal sectors with 2 green. What is P(green on both)?
7.SP.8.explanation: P(green on A)=1/4 and P(green on B)=2/5. For both: 1/4 x 2/5 = 2/20 = 1/10.

choices.label: A
choices.misconception_text: Oops! It looks like the counts were added together. For two separate events happening at the same time, we'll want to multiply the odds!

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. When we multiply 4 sectors by 5 sectors, we get a total of 20 different possible combinations on the bottom.

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful! For the top of our fraction, we multiply "1 green" times "2 greens," which gives us just 2 winning combinations out of 20.

7.SP.8.stem: A simulation of rolling two fair dice 600 times produced sum 7 exactly 92 times. Best experimental probability estimate for sum 7 is:
7.SP.8.explanation: Experimental probability is event frequency divided by total trials: 92/600.

choices.label: B
choices.misconception_text: Oops! 7 is the *sum* we want, but the probability is the number of successes (92) over the total trials (600)!

choices.label: C
choices.misconception_text: Not quite. 7 is just the goal we're aiming for. We need to use the actual count (92) of how many times that sum actually happened!

choices.label: D
choices.misconception_text: Careful! It seems the fraction was flipped. Probability is always successes divided by the total number of tries!
